member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionItem.GetCreateScript(System.String)
member.summary: Get a specific script to create a collection item that belongs to this set. It can either be called when the set is altered, in which case the set_id will be known, or when the set is being created, in which case it assumes the script for creating the collection set has already stored its id in a declared variable with its name stored in the setParamName argument.
member.param: parameter name created for holding the set id, null if not needed

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionItem.GetAlterScript
member.summary: We will need this script as part of the alter action in collection set Alter(), hence the "internal" modifier.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.Create
member.summary: Create a collection set on the config store

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.ScriptAlter
member.summary: Script alter for collection set objects

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.Alter
member.summary: Alter the collection set on the config store. Only the schedule, the target, the proxy, and the description could be updated. Items can also be added dropped or altered

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.Drop
member.summary: Drop the collectoin set from the config store

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.Stop
member.summary: Stop collection from a running collection set

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.Start
member.summary: Start collection from a collection set

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.Upload
member.summary: Do an on demand upload on the collection set to the Management Data Warehouse. Only meaningful if the collection mode is "Cached" and the set is currently running.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.RunOnce
member.summary: Run a collection and upload once, on demand. A single snapshot of data will be collected and uploaded to the Management Data Warehouse. Can only be used if the collection mode is "NonCached".

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.Cleanup
member.summary: This method cleans up all activities done while configuring/starting/running this collection set Cleanup tasks: Delete collect, upload jobs Change set's state to out of the box settings Set Data collector to non-configured state if this collection set is the last running set Delete all collection set logs
member.remarks: This method does not delete the collection set from MSDB tables

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.PostCreate(System.Object)
member.summary: A call back with the result of executing the create script. The execution result is a data set of tables. The first table contains the id and the uid of the newly created set, the following tables each contain an id of one of the collection items

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.PostAlter(System.Object)
member.summary: This is called with the result of executing the alter script. Since we have indicated it to return a data set, we expect it to be so. The data set consists of a table of singletons, each with the id of a newly added items.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.PostDrop(System.Object)
member.summary: Called after drop is done.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.StartStopUpload(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Will perform the main function for start/stop/upload.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.GetCreateScript
member.summary: Scripting a collection set requires creating the set and all its collection items in one batch. So, it is comprised of several small sub-scripts, one for creating the set and one for each of its items. To preserve the data integrity, everything is lumped into one transaction. If any of the sub-scripts fails the whole transactions is rolled back. The script return multiple rowsets. Each rowset represents the output id of the object that created on the backend store. In the furture, it might also include the object GUID.

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.GetCreateSetScript(System.String@)
member.param: variable name in the script that holds the value of the set id

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.GetAlterScript
member.summary: We need transactional symantics here for the same reasons we need them on the Create() interface. See comments for GetCreateScript()

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.GetAlterItemScript(Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionItem)
member.summary: The script for a child item depends on its state, which can be one of three things: 1- Pending: newly created, get a create script and mark the item as existing 2- Existing: already existing on the backend, get an alter script and don't change state 3- ToBeDropped: will be removed from the collection when parent altered or dropped, get a delete script and mark the item as dropped

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.GetDropScript
member.summary:
In the drop script, we don't need to have transactional symantics since the server will guarantee that all items belonging to a collection set are removed when the set is removed. This is by virtue of the cascading delete constraint on the item.
So, we only need to generate a drop script for the collection set

member.summary: Gets script to cleanup a collection set

member.summary: Creates script to cleanup a collection set

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.CollectionModes
member.summary: Different execution modes for a collection set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.CollectionModes.Cached
member.summary: The collection part of the collection set executes continuously, while the upload part is driven by a SQL Agent Schedule. The data is cached locally between scheduled uploads

member.name: F:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.CollectionSet.CollectionModes.NonCached
member.summary: Execution of the collection set is driven by a SQL Agent schedule. Data is collected and uploaded to the Management Data Warehouse on the spot.

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.Helpers

member.name: M:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.Helpers.CheckPropertyValueLength(System.String,System.Int32,System.String)
member.summary: Checks the value of a certain string property to make sure it is within its specified length. If the check fails, throws a collector exception.

member.name: T:HighestIncompatibleMDWVersion
member.summary:
This is a singleton class that includes the highest version of the MDW database that is incompatible with the current collector. Whenever an MDW ships with a breaking schema/API change from the previous version, the value has to change to reflect this.
IF YOU CHANGE THE VALUE HERE, PLEASE CHANGE THE CORRESPONDING VALUE IN THE STORED PROC sp_syscollector_get_highest_incompatible_mdw_version IN MSDB

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.TsqlProcFormatter.RuntimeArg

member.name: F:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.TsqlProcFormatter.RuntimeArg.isScript
member.summary: true if added because of a script type argument, if so, ignore the type and print out the value literally

member.name: T:Microsoft.SqlServer.Management.Collector.TsqlProcFormatter.ScriptTypeArg
member.summary: This struct is used for arguments that are generated using an arbitrary script. The script is assumed to be correct and properly escaped. The script is a string format that takes one parameter to be filled by the name of the generated variable name

member.summary: The name of the argument should match the name of the procedure argument name
